text: [Music]
so I think the generation gap is bigger
than the um the digital divide it's a
generational divide because if you go to
these um many of these developing
nations a lot of these kids have mobile
phones the cost of mobile phones have
gone down quite a bit and they're in
touch with with each other they text
each other and stuff like that and of
course if you go all the way down to the
tail there is are people who don't have
phones and in in Burma they're illegal
right so but but I think in in many many
markets where we consider them
disconnected the mobile devices is is is
filling that Gap and so and if you look
at the Nokia devices you know they're
they're going into very very um um poor
countries right now and so I think that
that there there is a digital divide but
as the mobile devices get cheaper and
smarter I think that that divide will
start close and I think the bigger Gap
will be the parents who don't know how
to use this stuff and even if they know
how to use it technically they haven't
changed their behavior around it like
these kids have so although the parents
in Japan use the same phone they don't
behave the way the kids do but the kids
are changing their behavior and I think
like I I hang out in the Middle East and
all the kids in the Middle East are just
like the kids in Japan more similar to
the kids in Japan than they are with
their parents
